ThingDef.label: Springfield Model 1861
ThingDef.description: USA. The Springfield Model 1861 is a rifled musket, its muzzle loading system and old ammunition type make it quite slow to reload and innacurate. However because it's "old tech" you only need "smithing" to start producing this rifle.

ThingDef.label: Remington Rolling Block
ThingDef.description: USA. Arriving a little too late for the Civil War, the Rolling Block saw service in 40 different countries all around the world. Easy to use, to manufacture and to maintain.

ThingDef.label: Springfield Trap Door Model 1873
ThingDef.description: USA. The Springfield Trap door was a muzzle-loader rifle converted to accept metal-case cartidge.

ThingDef.label: Krag-Jorgensen Model 1898
ThingDef.description: USA.Originally designed and build in Norway and later built under licence in the US, The Krag-Jorgensen serie of rifles was quite the improvement for the US Army in comparison of the Springfield Trap Door Model 1873, It was later replace by the well known Springfield 1903.

ThingDef.label: Spencer Repeating Carbine
ThingDef.description: USA. The Spencer Repeating Carbine aw designed in 1860 by Christopher Spencer in 1860.

ThingDef.label: Henry Model 1860
ThingDef.description: USA. The Henry Rifle was the incestor of the iconic Winchester rifle of the Wild West.

ThingDef.label: Winchester Model 1866
ThingDef.description: USA. The Winchester Model 1866 is the the first of a long serie of iconic carbine. Still cambered in the kinda weak .44 Henry.

ThingDef.label: Winchester Model 1873
ThingDef.description: USA. The Winchester Model 1873 is the most produced model of the iconic carbine. Now chambered in the more powerful .44-40WCF.

ThingDef.label: New Model Evans Carbine
ThingDef.description: USA. New Model Evans Carbine is the .44 Evans Long carbine version of the Evans Rifle. Its magazine size is really impressive for the time but its special mechanism make it a slow gun to reload and an expensive gun to make.

ThingDef.label: Winchester Model 1886
ThingDef.description: USA. The Winchester Model 1886 is an other varriant of the classic carbine, this time chambered in the powerfull 45-70 Government.

ThingDef.label: Blunderbuss
ThingDef.description: Everywhere. The last models of this antique firearme so action in tghe US during the revolution of 1776. Like the springfield 1961 it is considered as "low tech" so "smithing" is enough to craft this thing.

ThingDef.label: Double-barrel Shotgun
ThingDef.description: Everywhere. Double barrel Shotgun. Two shot in the barel and and a short range but deadly.

ThingDef.label: Double-barrel Shotgun
ThingDef.description: Everywhere. Double barrel Shotgun. Two shot in the barel and and a short range but deadly. Home made shortened version.

ThingDef.label: Winchester Model 1887
ThingDef.description: USA. Sarah Connor ?

ThingDef.label: Winchester Model 1897
ThingDef.description: USA. One of the more prolific shotgun in US history. A legend of the late XIX century Far West, of the Prohibition Era, Two World Wars and the Vietnam War.

ThingDef.label: Browning A5
ThingDef.description: USA. The Browning A5 is a semi-automatic shotgun that came out in 1903 and was in production for more than a century.

ThingDef.label: Colt Single Action Army
ThingDef.description: USA. The Colt Single Action Army was one of the more iconic and widespread revolver of the 2nd half of the XIXth century in the US. Its a good and relliable weapon but quite slow to reload. Chambered in .45 Colt.

ThingDef.label: Colt Single Action Army
ThingDef.description: USA. The Colt Single Action Army was one of the more iconic and widespread revolver of the 2nd half of the XIXth century in the US. Its a good and relliable weapon but quite slow to reload. This time with the more powerful .44-40 WCF.

ThingDef.label: SW Model 3 Scofield
ThingDef.description: USA. The Scofield.

ThingDef.label: SW Model 3 Scofield
ThingDef.description: USA. The Scofield.

ThingDef.label: Colt New Army
ThingDef.description: USA. The Colt New Army was the standard issue sidearm of the US Army until 1911. It's a Double action revolver way easier to relaod than its predecessor. Chambered in .41 Long Colt.

ThingDef.label: Borchardt C93
ThingDef.description: Imperial Germany. One of the frists semi-auto pistol coming from the Mauser's factories but not designed by Paul Mauser.

ThingDef.label: Mauser C96
ThingDef.description: Imperial Germany. One of the firsts semiautomatic pistols adopted by the German Imperial Army, it remained in service up until WWII.

ThingDef.label: FN Browning Model 1900
ThingDef.description: Belgium/USA. A semi-auto pistol designed by John Browning in 1896 and finalised in 1900 for the Belgian arms manufacturer FN.

ThingDef.label: FN Browning Model 1903
ThingDef.description: Belgium/USA. A semi-auto pistol designed by John Browning in 1903 for the Belgian arms manufacturer FN.
